posts.com:
Not long ago I married an American, after dating for quite a bit and deciding that this would be the best move for us.

I am Eastern European and I have been raised to have uppermost respect for elderly people and for in-laws. In my country we never consider our in-laws to be family and we keep a comfortable distance in the relationship we have with them. And here's the issue. American's are the opposite; apparently I married (as quoted) "into the family" and not into my husband.

I am expected to treat them how an American in-law would treat them, I am expected to pick up on their traditions, values and ways of living. Spending my whole life in Europe you cannot take the European out of me, and this is something my new "family" doesn't understand. My husband is very understanding, especially after meeting my family and spending some time in Europe with me. He would never, and was never, expected to behave the way I am expected to behave here.

Is there any way I can speak any sense into the boomers, or should I just wait it out until we can move far away from my in-laws? I don't hate them, I don't have anything against them, they just will never feel like or be my family. I don't wish to be treated like family because it makes me feel very uncomfortable and a lot of it seems fake. I understand that I can't change them, just like they can't change me. I am looking for any middle ground where both parties can be satisfied.

I want your opinions about all of this, be it positive or negative. Sure, I did ask for all of it myself by marrying internationally.

Also hello to my husband, he hangs out on 4chan a lot.

So what I did was just pretended I wasn’t scared shitless to be flirting with a girl. It was a lot of trial and error. It’s very likely not going to work the way you want it to for the first few dates. The first two girls I went out with were definitely beneath me on the attractiveness level, but I still couldn’t project confidence when I was talking to them, so they both rejected me. We had nothing to talk about. With the 3rd girl we had some commonalities (we both watched a few of the same TV shows and liked some of the same movies) so I was able to keep the conversation flowing well as long as I stayed within those boundaries. The fact that I came off charming talking about things we both knew about helped me a lot. It was pure happenstance that she ended up being easy. If she wasn’t, I probably would’ve had more trouble. But lucky for me she was ready to fuck 24 hours after meeting me. Bottom line: at first, just get what you can get. Even if they’re not hot. They’re basically just practice dummies. Still be nice to them, but go in knowing you’ll cast them aside after you get what you need. It helps a lot. Nervousness starts to melt away. Keep them at arm’s length from the rear of your life, though. Don’t introduce them to family or friends. Likely those early relationships won’t get to those points, but be careful that they don’t (unless you end up actually falling for one of the early one - which theoretically could happen, I guess). From there build up confidence and start aiming for girls you actually want to be with. You have to earn them.

First off let's define a dating app. A dating app is an app which functions as a digital matchmaking service. Examples include eHarmony, PoF, Elite Singles and Christian Mingle.

A dating app IS NOT a hook up app, where users swipe left and right or some other mechanic based on visuals and potentially a very short bio. Examples of hook up apps are Tinder & Bumble.

Now, to answer your question

>> can you actually find a decent woman on a dating app?

That depends on what you mean by decent, but the short answer is on a dating app, yes absolutely. You might have to do a fair bit of work to find one though.

Picrel however is of a hook up app. Hook up app are the digital equivalent of a seedy dive bar and are frequented by similar clientele. You won't find a decent woman there, decent women don't use hook up apps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28094836
>How, if at all, does one go about becoming a scientist, particularly a physicist, if not a quantum physicist, at home?
1) Study higher math, such as linear algebra, calculus, statistics, group theory, differential geometry, etc.
2) Study various areas of physics, such as classical mechanics, electrodynamics, optics, theoretical mechanics, quantum mechanics, field theory, general relativity, quantum field theory.
3) Pick a specific subfield to focus on and study it in more detail.
4) Identify an interesting unsolved problem in this subfield and work on solving it, or making substantial progress.
5) Publish a paper on your work.
6) There, now you're a physicist.

>I’m curious if this is “truly” possible
It's not impossible, but the likelihood of someone going through all this properly on his own, without being taught by actual physicists, is extremely low. Especially if your primary motivation is something unrelated to science itself.
>why don’t others bother doing it?
Why would anyone want to? If you want to spend years of your life studying something, might as well be taught by experts in it.

posts.sub: How do I get rid of my god complex?
posts.com:
Context: I am handsome, fit, and tall (6’3; get compliments from friends, family, strangers often), very smart (4.0 GPA and multiple professors have advised me to pursue a PhD), charismatic (always good friends with the people around me), and wealthy (scholarships + software engineering internships + got a lucrative job lined up post-graduation).

How can I stop thinking of the people around me as trash?

To begin with, I view all poor, ugly, short, colored, stupid, and disabled people as inherently worthless and in the back of my mind, I can’t help but scream that they should commit suicide because their continued living is simply not worth the trouble. In fact, the moment I notice a flaw in someone, I no longer view them as a person, but rather as a walking, breathing sack of meat that has no value whatsoever. I also intrinsically regard all good looking people as being stupid, I don't know why I have this bias because I know many people who are good looking and smart but even if I try to re-assure myself "this person is definitely smart - remember the time when they did X, which absolutely proved that?", I eventually slip back into my default attitude of treating them as incompetent idiots.

The worst is with my girlfriend - I jump back and forth between treating her like shit and worshipping her like a goddess to make up for that shitty behaviour. For example if she fucks up or I notice she has a flaw, I contemplate dumping her and ghost her and just generally give her the cold shoulder and trample over her feelings until I get over it. And then the next day I’ll be wracked with guilt and spoil her and ignore her shortcomings to make up for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Obviously I know that I have flaws too (this god complex being the most obvious one) but hypocritically, I am extremely forgiving to myself and can easily disregard them and view myself as perfect. When I was younger, I would literally become depressed over making a mistake on a test in school or a fuck up in a conversation but as I grew older and gained more confidence in myself, I started becoming more egotistical and hateful.

This isn't about "caring" it's a lack of motivation and an abundance of procrastination.

You feel bored because anything worth doing doesn't involve immediate gratification or instant no effort success.

Instead it involves mundane work, over a prolonged period of time to achieve meager delayed gratification. And as healthy as that is for you to engage with over the long term you switch off to it before you even get started because you lack self discipline and would rather involve yourself with frivolous interests like a small child.

So you're stuck feeling empty and unfulfilled in life doing things which provide no real or lasting benefits to your life. When really what you need to do is grow up, and force yourself to push through the initial boredom and stick with the things you know you need to be doing so you can benefit long term.

Yeah... or something like that.

I understand that feel. For too much of my life. And still do.

How I started to get out of that state was to work inward to see why this was the case. For me it was a number of things. Mainly depression. Took almost killing myself to make actual moves to get out of it.

Whatever it is, I think it has to be understood that there isn't going to initially be a drive to do it. It's going to take some motivation and force. For me, hiking was something I started. And every time I would have to talk myself into it. But I found that I usually felt better after doing so. Then I took my camera to take some pictures of nature and wildlife. In that' found an interest for photography. Then hiking became a result of doing photography as opposed to something I was forcing myself to do to be active. Still took some motivating to get me there sometimes but it was easier.

A lot of my depression comes from the feeling that I'm not doing as much as I should be. Or not where I should be at this point in my life. And it's a hard feeling to shrug but chipping away at that and just being whenever I can helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28096061

Meditation encompasses a broad swathe of practices that basically boil down to "learn how to slow your mind and bring your thoughts under your control by being able to let go of emotionally charged sensations and patterns of thinking."

Whatever form of "meditation" helps you get to that point is valuable for anyone. Some people pray, some people do more of the Westernized-Buddhist "empty your mind," etc. Try stuff out, see what works for you, a lot of it is basically a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy so understanding how that works will help you understand part of the goal of any given form of meditation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You can really damage yourself by doing meditation in an incorrect way, and it's very difficult to know if you're doing it right.
If you're going to do anything more than 10 minutes a day then please consider seeking the advice of a teacher or retreat.
If you're a beginner, 10 minutes a day can be a nice way to de-stress and chill. But there's a threshold where it stops being that and it starts giving you problems (like feeling sleepy or dull every time you sit to meditate, then this feeling of sleepiness carries into your daily life)

The dream:
>gain consciousness lying on my back during an extremely hot summer day on my elementary school playground
>A smiling asian-looking girl 7-8yo leans over me and reaches out to poke my nose
>I get the intense "danger" instinct like something terrible will happen if she touches me
>roll away and stand up to face a huge crowd of asian children staring at me
>they all run at me while smiling and laughing, trying to poke me
>enter fight or flight mode and start unloading huge punches on the crowd

IRL:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28087598
I understand the feeling as i had it as well, but this is the first obstacle you will face in creative industry.
What you thought?
Probably someone, somewhere thought already, and probably made it. Could be also some underrated gem waiting to be discovered later (see misunderstood cult movies, for example).
Copy without shame. Take notes from why you like to copy these things, and be proud of your inspirations. Take out things that clearly seems like you are just emulating a style. Add your details or stuff you really think it could be made better and with time you will be developing your style. Take your time as well as someone said before.
Then, later on, you will notice that after all is just a big combination game.
About overflowing, limit yourself with restraints.
You are writing a sci-fi story? Read only about sci-fi. Merging themes, styles and narratives are to be made when you got a solid frame for it, or else you risk it to become some post-modern mishmash that can be utter genious or pretentious scrambling (unless you aim to be a Pyncheon heh)

>>28087743
Not much, take your time again.
Go easy on yourself, keep your old works no matter how ashamed you feel from them. They will be a reminder that you had to pass through them in order to get where you wanted to be.
Always starts small and then try something little different.
Frank Herbert's Dune, for instance, was only to be about a planetologist fight to keep a planet.
Only later he found that his interest in leaders and religion effects on mankind could - emphasis to the COULD - be a nice fit to make it unique. But don't overthink if a idea seems good or not, feedback will say later for you what went fine and what haven't.
Stay safe anon, the bleeding hearts and artists make their stand.

Love is called "conditional" because the only person that can really love you "unconditionally" is your parent, because they created you, gave birth to you, raised you, its personal and you share a part of them in you.
Conditional love isn't real, its just someone that finds you attractive, that was spending enough time with you to "condition" themselves to your presence, re-creating that feeling of what they felt towards their parents as they spent their entire early life close to them and in their presence. Combine that feeling with an attraction, and the fact that you two are not related so its socially acceptable to find each other attractive to begin with and you get "love". This is why you are able to "love" multiple partners in your life time, but only unconditionally love your parents or your children. "Love" is conditional, because you condition yourself to be in a frame of mind that resembles love towards another person and we just call it love because we want to believe in how romantic it really can be, and that love and everything that it is is easier to just compress into one word, "love", which is handy when people want to get things done, like getting married, or develop a relationship, given that there is that factor of "love" present. This is why kids who grew up without parents early on in life, who didn't feel love, later in life struggle to develop relationships, because they don't know how to re-create that feeling of being loved unconditionally, to then attach that feeling to another person and say they "love" them.

>>28092138
Height is actually one of the few measurable traits that seems to have a direct, albeit weak, correlation with dick size. The caveat here is that sexual traits are, in all mammals, more variable than other traits - by which I mean something very particular. Think about how some girls have no tits and others have massive ones; some guys have a micropeen and others have Mandingo schlongs. Comparatively, other traits - like height itself for example - are normally distributed and less variable than sexual ones. This is why it's impossible to look at a tall guy and be sure he has a big dick, but you can be reasonably sure he has big feet or hands.
Why are sexual traits more variable? It's hard to say. One explanation may be that the genetic code for both sexes is mostly the same, barring a single chromosome. Perhaps our genetic code can't optimize on a sex-by-sex basis because it has to be beneficial for both sons and daughters. Another explanation is that sexual traits undergo more evolutionary selection and it is possible that more selection necessarily = more variance until a new equilibrium is established.

>I can go out and hold conversations with them
A lot of guys struggle with this so give yourself credit for this, you're already halfway there. Potentially turning it into something romantic with someone is more just a case of not being shy to flirt, escalate, make moves, eventually you'll get somewhere with someone. Obvs don't become a creeper who just hits on all his sister's friends, try to meet new girls too, but you can also meet people via them and expand your social network.
>recommend going to school far away
Hm I don't think you need to go far away, you can still live within commuting distance of home/your current friends, that way at least you have some contact and a "home base" if it takes longer to build connections in a new place.
>kinda want to try Cocaine
If you don't have a propensity for addiction then it's probably safe to try once with some trusted friends, but obvs still not a great idea.
If you have an addictive personality DO NOT TOUCH IT (or any drugs for that matter) I am dead serious here. There's a reason cokeheads say "once you pop you can't stop". You end up chasing that high and nothing else compares and you become increasingly self-destructive in your personal life just for one more high.
>>28096330
>isn't something I 100% believe I will have
I mean, no one is 100% confident that they'll live happily ever after, but you don't want that percentage to get too low, a bit of "fake it til you make it" and positive self-affirmation can help here.
>I tend to blame myself
It's good to take responsibility for some things and areas you can improve but do not fall into the mental trap of relentlessly beating yourself up and knocking your confidence even more. You're only human, it's OK to fuck up sometimes and be awkward and have intense feelings and not always know the right answer. As long as you are not actively being malicious and hurting others there is no reason to hate yourself.

>>28096641
Science graduate here.

"Cross" can mean "interbreed", and there is a long tradition of jokes in English that have the form "What do you get if cross X with Y?" e.g. "What do you get if you cross a kangaroo with an elephant? Large holes all over Australia."

Anopheles mosquitos carry and spread malaria, so, in epidemiology terms, they are a "disease vector".

Mountain goats are good at climbing things - "scale" is a word meaning "climb", so they are "scalers".

In applied maths, a vector is something that has both magnitude and direction (e.g. a velocity - 70mph due east) while a "scalar" is something that only has magnitude (e.g. temperature). There are two different ways of multiplying a vector, which use a dot and a cross as their symbols. The "cross" operation requires two vectors, not a vector and a number; thus "you can't cross a vector with a scalar".

So it's a triple pun on "cross", "vector" and "scaler"/"scalar", that also subverts a well-known traditional joke format.

But as she said, no joke is remotely funny if it has to be explained. If you know all of the above already, and all of those concepts collide in your mind simultaneously, then it is kind of funny.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: there are different kinds of drunk. if you're just buzzed on a drink or two, it's sort of comparable to weed but a little less paranoid and more relaxed. if you're actually drunk though, i'd actually say it's sort of similar to opiates but more engaging. you feel a heavy sense of warmth and pleasure, but also numbness; it has an anesthetic effect that's good for dull pains. it can make you tired, but it can also make you more talkative, outgoing and creative. it also destroys fear to an extent, and may make you more likely to do or say things you otherwise wouldn't. if you get too drunk though, you will feel the worst you've ever felt in your life. you'll feel like you're on a non-stop rollercoaster, your entire body will be vibrating uncomfortably, the room will be spinning, and you will want to puke your guts out. alcohol is a weird substance.

>>28091198
First of all, try not to fall into the pitfalls of "I want to hurt myself" or "I want to hurt other people." If you don't want medications tell them that and they won't give you any.
Next tell them, the problem, and be honest. Go on with humility and be open to their help. Be prepared to tell them your life story and don't take anything personally.
Also, tell them what you want and they will work with you to get it.
Be polite, have manners, and use common sense.
The foundation of this relationship is honesty. Trust is important too but the psychology is expecting you to not give them unwarranted trust, and you don't have to do anything you don't want to.

That being said, don't run away if you're afraid or embarrassed.

He tore up.

Don't forget to drink water, it helps to avoid a hangover, and it may take a few hours to pass. Some people eat carby or fatty foods to "absorb the alcohol".

Personally I don't like to just sit in the quiet and dwell on it, if I'm really drunk that just gives me the spins and makes me feel more sick. In that case it helps to distract your drunk mind with something, like an activity, conversation, or video game perhaps. But everyone copes differently, if you're not used to being drunk you won't know what works for you yet.

The perfect way to drink is not to drink too much to feel sick and/or throw up, but to still feel a nice buzz. Try to enjoy yourself and relax, and avoid getting angry, depressive, or violent.
